name: 1,6-dimethyl-1H-pyrazolo[3,4-b]pyridine
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1851

name: 1,6-dimethyl-1H-pyrazolo[3,4-b]pyridine
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1851
Reason: To predict the melting point of 1,6-dimethyl-1H-pyrazolo[3,4-b]pyridine, we start by considering the basic structural unit, pyridine, which has a melting point of around -42°C. However, pyrazolo[3,4-b]pyridine is a fused bicyclic structure, leading to increased rigidity and a higher melting point. The insertion of nitrogen atoms into the ring structure generally increases melting points due to additional hydrogen bonding. Here, we have three additional nitrogen atoms, which we can estimate to increase the melting point significantly. The two methyl groups will also raise the melting point due to increased molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, but to a lesser extent than the effect of the ring structure and nitrogen atoms. Considering these factors, I predict the following incremental increases to the melting point: Bicyclic structure: +120°C, Nitrogen atoms: +20°C each (total of +60°C), Methyl groups: +5°C each (total of +10°C). Therefore, the predicted melting point would be the sum of these effects.
Prediction: Pyridine base value (-42) + Bicyclic structure (+120) + Nitrogen atoms (3x+20 = +60) + Methyl groups (2x+5 = +10) = -42 + 120 + 60 + 10 = 148°C

name: 1,6-dimethyl-1H-pyrazolo[3,4-b]pyridine
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1851
Reason: To predict the melting point of 1,6-dimethyl-1H-pyrazolo[3,4-b]pyridine, we start with the basic structural unit, pyridine, which has a low melting point of around -42°C. The presence of a fused bicyclic ring system in pyrazolo[3,4-b]pyridine structure greatly increases the melting point due to increased molecular rigidity and planarity. We can estimate the influence of the bicyclic system to significantly raise the melting point. Each nitrogen atom in the ring can contribute to higher melting points through increased hydrogen bonding capabilities. For three nitrogen atoms, this effect can be considerable. The introduction of two methyl groups further increases the melting point due to the added molecular weight and van der Waals forces. To quantify, the effects could be estimated as: Bicyclic structure: +180°C due to rigid and planar structure enhancing crystal stability, Nitrogen atoms: +10°C each because of potential hydrogen bonding (total of +30°C), Methyl groups: +5°C each due to a slight increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions (total of +10°C). Adding these increments to the base value of pyridine gives a predicted melting point.
Prediction: Pyridine base value (-42) + Bicyclic structure (+180) + Nitrogen atoms (3x+10 = +30) + Methyl groups (2x+5 = +10) = -42 + 180 + 30 + 10 = 178°C
